title: It’s Bayes All The Way Up
summary:
Key ideas:
- Bayes’ Theorem is a mathematical framework for integrating new evidence with prior beliefs
- The brain performs top-down processing which involves letting its models of the world influence perceptions
- Perception is a “handshake” between top-down and bottom-up processing
- Organic psychosis, like schizophrenia, might involve disruptions in sensory processing
- Autism is a form of aberrant precision where confidence intervals are too low causing an inability to “smooth over” bottom-up information
- Autistic people have sensory gating problems that lead to difficulty regulating sensory input.
- Autistic people dislike social interaction because it is unpredictable.
- Autistic people engage in stimming behaviors as an attempt to control their sensory environment.
- Autistic people might benefit from weighted blankets due to the predictability of sensory input.

Key learnings:
- The neurotransmitters in the brain might represent different terms in Bayes’ Theorem
- Top-down models predict what we’re going to see, bottom-up models perceive the real world, then they meet in the middle and compare notes to calculate a prediction error
- Schizophrenics and people stoned on marijuana are more likely to properly identify the face as concave than everyone else
- LSD bottoms out in the pattern of increased AMPA and increased NMDA that we would expect to produce hallucinations
- Autism is a form of aberrant precision where confidence intervals are too low causing an inability to “smooth over” bottom-up information
- Autistic people struggle with sensory gating, and this can affect their perception of the world around them.
- Autistic people have difficulty with social interaction because it is hard to extract meaningful information from unpredictable sensory input.
- Stimming behaviors can be seen as an attempt to control the sensory environment.
- Weighted blankets might be helpful to autistic people because they provide a high degree of predictable sensory input.

Key questions:
- What is the relationship between top-down processing and bottom-up processing?
- How do disruptions in sensory processing lead to organic psychosis?
- Why do increasing levels of dopamine lead to narrowed confidence intervals and increased certainty?
- How does sensory deprivation impact sensory processing and resulting perceptions?
- What is the relative role of NMDA and AMPA in producing hallucinations and delusions?
- If psychosis is a case of attenuated priors, why do delusions become so fixed in psychotic individuals?
- What is the difference between mild surprise and annoyance-based prediction errors and belief in delusions of reference?
